name: E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase HERC2
function_summary: The HERC2 gene encodes a 527 kDa E3 ubiquitin protein ligase enzyme that has key roles in cell cycle regulation, spindle formation during mitosis, mitochondrial functions and DNA damage responses.
function_description: The chance of getting blue eyes is known to be dependent on variants present in the HERC2 and OCA2 genes.

If there are no variants in any of the 2 genes, the P-protein that is encoded by the OCA2 gene is produced correctly and in enough amounts for it to be used in melanin production leading to a brown eye phenotype.

If there is a variant in HERC2 (transcription binding site for OCA2), transcription of the OCA2 gene is inhibited and no or minimum amounts of the P-protein is produced, which leads to no to reduced production in the eye, leading to a blue eyed phenotype.

The Blue eyed phenotype is produced as well when there is a variant in the OCA2 gene.  A variant in the OCA2 gene may result in a P protein that is not formed correctly and the p-protein cannot be used properly in melanin production.
function_citation: Elpidorou, M. et al. (2020) ‘Novel loss-of-function mutation in herc2 is associated with severe developmental delay and paediatric lethality’, Journal of Medical Genetics, 58(5), pp. 334–341. doi:10.1136/jmedgenet-2020-106873.
